FacilityName: United States Cold Storage LP-Cockrell Hill Dallas

_prev_prog_3.PC_OtherType: Water diffusion tank for PSRV system

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
United States Cold Storage (USCS) is committed to the safe operation of all our facilities to protect our employees, the public, and the environment.  This is accomplished to a great extent by compliance with our detailed Risk Management and Process Safety Management programs.  These programs are designed to meet or exceed the standards set out by OSHA (29 CFR 1910.119), the EPAs Risk Management Plan Rule, and other applicable state and local requirements.

United States Cold Storage Cockrell Hill Dallas is a public refrigerated warehouse that stores raw or processed food items (such as those found in your local supermarkets or restaurants) prior to distribution.  Temperatures of the different product storage areas can range from -40?F to +40?F.  Our refrigeration process uses a chemical known as anhydrous ammonia and carbon dioxide contained within a closed-loop system.  

Anhydrous ammonia has been used safely in commercial refrigeration applications since the early 1900s.  It has an excellent warning property, which is a distinct and irritating odor which can be detected at concentrations as low as 5 PPM (parts per million) in air.  Most people are familiar with the smell as it is a common ingredient in many household cleaning products.

The total refrigerant charge at USCS Cockrell Hill Dallas is approximately 13,616 pounds and 63,197 pounds of carbon dioxide.  Throughout the process, most of the ammonia resides within pressure-rated vessels inside of a specially constructed machinery room.  During the cooling/freezing process, liquid carbon dioxide is pumped from a vessel through piping to evaporator units in each area that needs cooling such as the storage rooms or docks.  As carbon dioxide passes through the evaporator, it pulls heat from the surrounding area and changes from a liquid into a vapor within the pipes.  That vapor is sent to a cascade condenser in the machinery room, where the outside of the coils is cooled by anhydrous ammonia, getting rid of

the excess/unwanted heat, and changing back from a vapor to a liquid before flowing back to the vessel to close the loop and start the process over.  

All refrigeration equipment has been designed, manufactured, and installed in accordance with strict regulations such as the ASME Boiler and Pressure Vessel Code, applicable Building, Fire, and Mechanical codes, as well as industry specific standards published by the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration.  

This equipment is maintained according to the preventative maintenance schedules laid out in the most current edition of ANSI/IIAR6 Standard for Inspection, Testing, and Maintenance of Closed-Circuit Ammonia Refrigeration Systems.  An electronic control system monitors conditions 24-7 and will automatically notify maintenance staff of any abnormal operating conditions.

In addition, there are dozens of safety measures in place.  A few examples include:

	Ammonia detectors in the engine room
	Carbon dioxide detectors in product storage areas and docks
	Automatic system shutdowns
	Pressure Safety Relief Valves on critical equipment
	Manual emergency-stops
	Etc.

Our refrigeration systems are operated by a staff of specially trained maintenance personnel, many of whom are members of IIAR (International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration) and/or RETA (Refrigerating Engineers and Technicians Association).  

USCS has owned/operated the Cockrell Hill Dallas location since 2013.  The facility has not had a release resulting in employee injuries or off-site impacts in that time.

USCS Cockrell Hill Dallas maintains emergency response and emergency action plans which are reviewed and updated annually.  These programs are based on the OSHA requirements found in 29 CFR 1910.38, 1910.119, and 1910.120, in addition to all applicable EPA and other local/state requirements.

Each USCS location has first responders trained in emergency response (24-hr hazmat technician level specializing in ammonia releases).  T

hese employees receive a minimum of four hours of refresher training annually.  Each site conducts simulated emergency response drills quarterly and joint training exercises with local fire departments/hazmat teams/emergency planning committees whenever possible.

USCS Cockrell Hill Dallas will be implementing a new administrative feature for disabling or bypassing controls using reusable note cards for communication of temporary control system changes.
